Literature Review: Fatty acid-binding proteins (FABPs) are a family of small, cytosolic proteins that play crucial roles in lipid metabolism and cellular signaling. These proteins are highly conserved across mammalian species and are characterized by their ability to bind and transport fatty acids (FAs) within cells. Over the years, extensive research has expanded our understanding of FABPs, revealing their multifaceted functions and implications in various physiological and pathological processes. Initially, FABPs were primarily recognized for their role in intracellular FA transport. Studies by Binas et al. (2006) demonstrated that FABPs facilitate the uptake and intracellular trafficking of FAs, which are essential for energy production and membrane synthesis. However, it has become evident that FABPs' functions extend far beyond simple transport. For instance, FABPs have been implicated in the regulation of gene expression, particularly through their interactions with nuclear receptors. Kostner et al. (2008) reported that FABPs can modulate the activity of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), which are key regulators of lipid metabolism and inflammation. The tissue-specific expression patterns of FABPs further highlight their diverse roles. For example, heart-type FABP (H-FABP) is predominantly found in cardiac and skeletal muscle, where it plays a critical role in FA metabolism and energy homeostasis (Binas et al., 2006). In contrast, liver-type FABP (L-FABP) is highly expressed in the liver and intestines, where it is involved in the absorption and metabolism of dietary FAs (Kostner et al., 2008). These distinct expression patterns suggest that FABPs are tailored to meet the specific metabolic needs of different tissues. Recent studies have also uncovered the involvement of FABPs in systemic metabolism. For example, adipocyte FABP (A-FABP) has been linked to insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. Hotamisligil et al. (1994) found that A-FABP levels are elevated in obese individuals and correlate with insulin resistance. Similarly, FABP4 has been shown to contribute to the development of atherosclerosis by promoting foam cell formation and inflammation in vascular walls (Hotamisligil et al., 1994). In addition to their roles in metabolism, FABPs have been implicated in cancer progression. Research by Tanaka et al. (2005) revealed that FABP5 is overexpressed in various types of cancer, including breast, prostate, and colon cancer. FABP5 has been shown to enhance tumor growth and metastasis by facilitating the uptake and utilization of FAs for energy production and cell proliferation (Tanaka et al., 2005). Furthermore, FABP5 has been linked to the activation of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR), which is involved in the regulation of gene expression and cellular responses to environmental toxins (Tanaka et al., 2005). The ligand binding repertoire of FABPs is not limited to long-chain FAs. Studies by Storch et al. (2007) have shown that FABPs can also bind other lipophilic molecules, such as eicosanoids and retinoids. This broad binding capacity suggests that FABPs may have additional functions in cellular signaling and homeostasis. For instance, FABP7, which is highly expressed in the brain, has been implicated in the regulation of neurogenesis and brain development (Storch et al., 2007). The potential for FABPs to be secreted and exert effects via the circulation has also been explored. Research by Kostner et al. (2008) indicated that certain FABPs, such as L-FABP, can be released into the bloodstream and may serve as biomarkers for various diseases. Elevated levels of circulating L-FABP have been associated with liver injury and dysfunction, making it a potential diagnostic tool (Kostner et al., 2008). In conclusion, the multifunctional nature of FABPs underscores their importance in lipid metabolism, cellular signaling, and disease pathogenesis. Understanding the complex roles of FABPs in health and disease may provide new therapeutic targets for the treatment of metabolic disorders, inflammation, and cancer. Future research should focus on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying FABP functions and exploring their potential as biomarkers and therapeutic agents.
